data.title: Pranjal Chalise Felicitated as Wai Wai Glocal Teen Hero Nepal 2021
data.snippet:
Likewise, He has developed a mobile application that provides agricultural news and information from authentic sources and another app includes-a Women Safety app to ensure the security of women and ensure they are not deprived of opportunities due to their safety reasons.

His other two educational apps have 7500 users. Pranjal has also initiated a non-profit tech venture E-educators Nepal‚Äô, which enhances the quality of online education and makes educational resources more accessible.

Furthermore, He is the member of the board of Initiative in Nepal Foundation, and currently working on a research paper about the Blockchain Technology and Smart Contracts and the ways in which technological advancement can mitigate the costs of elongated transaction processes. [...] Mr. Pranjal was selected among the Top Six Finalists of the competition viz Mr. Anurag Chapagain, (18 years, Youtuber, Nawalparasi); Mr. Deepak Sutihar (19 years, Social Entrepreneur, Saptari); Ms. Khusbu Bhandari, (18 years,Wildlife Conservationist, Chitwan); Ms. Neha Gurung, (19 years, Social Activist, Kathmandu); and Ms. Sabhya Rai, (19 years, Education Activist, IIam)

Mr. Pranjal Chalise has aided the Blind Community by inventing Drishti Nepal, which helps the blind community in currency bills recognition and cash transactions. [...] These teenagers were selected from a pool of 611 applications from across the nation, by our respected jury panel through an intense selection round for the impacts they have created in society.

The applicants had demonstrated their skills and expertise, and made an impact in their society, from areas like academia, social work, literature, entrepreneurship, computer programming, innovation, and environmental conservation.

This award recognizes and honors the exceptional teen whose work is sustainable and who can think out of the box addressing the issues and creating an impact in society.

KMC has provided me with a solid foundation for academic excellence, with a perfect blend of classroom learning and extracurricular activities that have helped me grow as an individual.
Apart from academics, KMC also offers a wide range of activities and clubs that have helped me explore my interests and develop my skills. These experiences have not only enriched my personal growth but have also helped me build strong relationships with my peers.

data.title: Team Tumornators | An Incubate Nepal Project
data.snippet:
2021

## Pranjal Chalise

Team Kisan, Team Drishti(2020)

‚ÄúA surreal utopia where friends turned into F.R.I.E.N.D.S, and fanatics into professionals. Contributing to two different teams- ‚ÄòTeam Kisan' and ‚ÄòTeam Drishti' was overwhelming but the realization that, through my projects, I could deliver ripple effects in the community- be it in the lives of farmers or differently-abled people, was certainly more promising. A bunch of high-school pass-outs coming together to create impacts on society sounds a bit fancy. At Incubate Nepal you'll witness countless such fancy sugarcoats turning into real-life realities.‚Äù

2020

## Anupa Khanal

Team Brahmanda(2020) [...] 2021

## Aayusha Dhungana

Team Samsad(2021)

‚ÄúPolitics and Social science, something that I was not really fond of. But to my own surprise, I was paired up with my team mates to build a website featuring parliament system of Nepal. Entering the whole new world of website building and politics surely frightened me, but the continuous support from the mentor and my wonderful team made this whole journey very smooth and informative. Incubate Nepal, helped me break my comforting cocoon and stand out in the crowd to learn, take challenges and share tons of memories with the whole team.‚Äù

2021

## Pranjal Chalise

Team Kisan, Team Drishti(2020) [...] ## Surya Tripathi

  Surya grew up as a farmer in the beautiful village of Hemja in Pokhara. He attended Gandaki Boarding School starting from primary school and studied IB diploma in the UK through Pestalozzi Trust. After taking a gap year, he got into MIT as a bioengineering major. where he developed a passion in microbiology and preventive medicine. Surya has numerous publications in Nature and Cell in these topics. Currently, he is a PhD student at UC Berkeley, and aside from research, loves mentoring and helping students.
 Organizer

  ## Simanta Gautam

data.title: Enhancing autonomous systems with bayesian neural ...
data.snippet:
### 2.2 Bayesian neural networks and uncertainty modeling

BNNs extend standard neural networks by treating weights as probability distributions rather than fixed parameters. This allows the model to capture both epistemic (model-related) and aleatoric (input-related) uncertainty (Kendall and Gal, 2017). Methods such as variational inference and Monte Carlo dropout enable practical approximations for training and inference (Mena et al., 2021).

BNNs have been applied successfully in healthcare (Ngartera et al., 2024), object tracking (Nie et al., 2018), and risk-sensitive control. However, most implementations focus on static perception tasks. The application of BNNs in full-stack autonomous navigation‚Äìparticularly for planning and trajectory prediction‚Äìremains underexplored. [...] The rapid evolution of autonomous systems is reshaping urban mobility and accelerating the development of intelligent transportation networks. A key challenge in real-world deployment is the ability to operate reliably under uncertainty‚Äìarising from sensor noise, dynamic agents, and adverse weather conditions. This paper investigates Bayesian Neural Networks (BNNs) as a principled framework for uncertainty-aware decision-making in autonomous navigation. Through three representative case studies‚Äìurban navigation, obstacle avoidance, and weather-induced visual degradation‚Äìwe demonstrate how BNNs outperform deterministic neural networks by providing calibrated predictions and uncertainty estimates. These probabilistic outputs enable conservative and interpretable decision-making in high-risk [...] ‚Ä¢ Performance Gains: BNNs achieved an 18.3% reduction in mean path deviation under high-uncertainty scenarios.

### 4.5 Quantitative error comparison across scenarios

We further evaluated performance across four urban contexts: open roads, intersections, occluded turns, and fog conditions. BNNs consistently showed lower deviation from ground truth, particularly under sensory or environmental uncertainty.

### 4.6 Discussion and conclusion

This case study validates the advantage of modeling uncertainty in urban navigation. BNNs offer better calibration, interpretability, and safety margins than deterministic counterparts.

#### 4.6.1 Limitations

Trade-offs include:

‚Ä¢ Inference Time: Sampling increases computation.

data.title: [PDF] Journal of Foot and Ankle Surgery (Asia Pacific)
data.snippet: Abstracts Presented at the Annual Meeting of Indian Foot and Ankle Society (IFASCON 2019) at New Delhi, 2019 Journal of Foot and Ankle Surgery (Asia-Pacific), Volume 6 Issue 2 (July‚ÄìDecember 2019) 61 They were graded on basis of residual pain, foot shape, and movements. Best results were seen in cases where rigid intertarsal/intercolumnar stability was achieved by screw fixation. There was residual inter-cuneiform subluxation in 4 cases, which were fixed with K-wires, and this led to residual pain. Conservative/neglected cases had poor results. Intercolumnar/intertarsal instabilities should be primarily recognized and stabilized under compression. Stabilization should not only be within the 3 columns but also intercolumnar, thus maintaining the relative length of three columns and hence [...] 12 months postoperatively. At 12 months, the mean AOFAS was 84.24. Five patients (20%) had score more then 90 (excellent), 11 (44%) had score between 81‚Äì90 (good), 8 (32%) had score between 71‚Äì80 (fair) and 1 (4%) had 70 (poor). Mean AOFAS score improved from 71.36 (at 3 month) to 79.96 (at 6 month) and 84.24 (at 1 year). Mean VAS score at the end of 1 year was 22.4 mm. 17(68%) cases in the study had fracture union without any complications.8 (32%) cases had postoperative complications ranging from superficial wound infection to delayed union and secondary arthrosis. Tibia pilon fractures are challanging injuries. A constant balance has to be maintained to get anatomical reduction with minimal soft tissue handling. In a closed and type one open fracture low profile LCP is best option. [...] of our study is to evaluate restoration of subtalar joint and functional outcomes in intrarticular displaced sanders type 2 and 3 calcaneal fractures treated with a minimally invasive sinus tarsi approach for posterior facet exposure and percutaneous screw and/or plate.
